name: Table

textContent.value: Table

This block is used to organize tabular data into a grid of rows and columns, making it easier for readers to compare and analyze information.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has multiple columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                Each subsequent row represents a row of data.
                Cells across the columns hold individual data points, headers, or labels as needed.
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will maintain a clear, tabular format, allowing for organized display and easy scanning of the information.
              When to use
              
                When presenting structured data that benefits from a clear row-and-column layout.
                To compare multiple data points side by side.
                If a quick, at-a-glance view of related information is necessary.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content consists of simple text or a single piece of information without comparisons.
                When a more visual or narrative presentation (e.g., charts or cards) better communicates the data.
                If interactivity or dynamic filtering is required beyond a static table.
Table (striped)

This block is used to organize tabular data into a grid of rows and columns, making it easier for readers to compare and analyze information. The ‘striped’ variant should be used when a background color should be set on every second row.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has multiple columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                Each subsequent row represents a row of data.
                Cells across the columns hold individual data points, headers, or labels as needed.
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will maintain a clear, tabular format, allowing for organized display and easy scanning of the information.
              When to use
              
                When presenting structured data that benefits from a clear row-and-column layout.
                To compare multiple data points side by side.
                If a quick, at-a-glance view of related information is necessary.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content consists of simple text or a single piece of information without comparisons.
                When a more visual or narrative presentation (e.g., charts or cards) better communicates the data.
                If interactivity or dynamic filtering is required beyond a static table.
Table (bordered)

This block is used to organize tabular data into a grid of rows and columns, making it easier for readers to compare and analyze information. The ‘bordered’ variant should be used when the table should have a border around each cell.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has multiple columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                Each subsequent row represents a row of data.
                Cells across the columns hold individual data points, headers, or labels as needed.
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will maintain a clear, tabular format, allowing for organized display and easy scanning of the information.
              When to use
              
                When presenting structured data that benefits from a clear row-and-column layout.
                To compare multiple data points side by side.
                If a quick, at-a-glance view of related information is necessary.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content consists of simple text or a single piece of information without comparisons.
                When a more visual or narrative presentation (e.g., charts or cards) better communicates the data.
                If interactivity or dynamic filtering is required beyond a static table.
Table (striped & bordered)

This block is used to organize tabular data into a grid of rows and columns, making it easier for readers to compare and analyze information. The ‘bordered’ and ‘striped’ variants should be used together when the table should have a border around each cell and every second row should have a background color set.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has multiple columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                Each subsequent row represents a row of data.
                Cells across the columns hold individual data points, headers, or labels as needed.
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will maintain a clear, tabular format, allowing for organized display and easy scanning of the information.
              When to use
              
                When presenting structured data that benefits from a clear row-and-column layout.
                To compare multiple data points side by side.
                If a quick, at-a-glance view of related information is necessary.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content consists of simple text or a single piece of information without comparisons.
                When a more visual or narrative presentation (e.g., charts or cards) better communicates the data.
                If interactivity or dynamic filtering is required beyond a static table.
Table (no header)

This block is used to organize tabular data into a grid of rows and columns, making it easier for readers to compare and analyze information. The 'no header’ variant should be used when the table does not have a header row.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has multiple columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                Each subsequent row represents a row of data.
                Cells across the columns hold individual data points or labels as needed.
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will maintain a clear, tabular format, allowing for organized display and easy scanning of the information.
              When to use
              
                When presenting structured data that benefits from a clear row-and-column layout.
                To compare multiple data points side by side.
                If a quick, at-a-glance view of related information is necessary.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content consists of simple text or a single piece of information without comparisons.
                When a more visual or narrative presentation (e.g., charts or cards) better communicates the data.
                If interactivity or dynamic filtering is required beyond a static table.

name: Columns

textContent.value: Columns

This block is used to present content side by side in multiple columns, providing a more structured, visually balanced layout.
              Implementation
              This block's table has multiple columns and rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                In subsequent rows, create as many cells (rows + columns) as needed for your layout. Base the number of columns on how the content is visually organized.
                Each cell can contain text, images, or other inline elements.
                As a rule, blocks must not be nested in other blocks.
                Additional rows may be added and must contain the same number of columns as the second row.
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will transform each cell into a column, displaying them in a responsive grid.
              Look at the source HTML structure and screenshots to determine the natural grouping of content that should become separate columns.
              When to use
              
                When you need to compare or present related content side by side.
                To organize lengthy copy or various media elements into a more digestible layout.
                When a balanced, multi-column arrangement supports better readability.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If you only need one column or a single piece of content.
                When each content piece requires its own distinct styling beyond simple columns.
                If a vertical layout or stacked design is more appropriate for your page structure.

name: Cards

textContent.value: Cards

This block is used to showcase distinct pieces of information in a consistent, card-based layout, each card typically containing an image, a title, and descriptive text.
              Implementation
              This block’s table has 2 columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants in parenthesis.
              Each subsequent row represents a single card and can include:
              
                Image or Icon (mandatory) - in the first cell of the row.
                Text content (mandatory) - in the second cell of the row. This cell can contain:
                  
                    Title (optional) – styled as a Heading.
                    Description (optional) - below the heading.
                    Call-to-Action (optional) - linked text at the bottom of the cell.
                  
                
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript transform each row into a card, arranging them in a grid or list layout based on available space.
              When to use
              
                To highlight multiple related features, products, or articles.
                When you want a uniform visual style for items with distinct content.
                To make a set of clickable, structured elements that are easy to scan.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If you need just a single feature or highlight, rather than multiple cards.
                When your layout requires more complex components or varied styling per item.
                If a simpler list or table layout better fits the content.
                If no images are present in the cards, consider the ‘no images’ variant
Cards (no images)

This block is used to showcase distinct pieces of information in a consistent, card-based layout, each card typically containing a title and descriptive text.
              Implementation
              This block’s table has 1 column and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants in parenthesis.
              Each subsequent row represents a single card and can include:
              
                Text content (mandatory) - in the first (and only) cell of the row. This cell can contain:
                  
                    Heading (optional)
                    Description (optional) - below the heading.
                    Call-to-Action (optional) - linked text at the bottom of the cell.
                  
                
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript transform each row into a card, arranging them in a grid or list layout based on available space.
              When to use
              
                To highlight multiple related features, products, or articles.
                When you want a uniform visual style for items with distinct content.
                To make a set of clickable, structured elements that are easy to scan.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If you need just a single feature or highlight, rather than multiple cards.
                When your layout requires more complex components or varied styling per item.
                If a simpler list or table layout better fits the content.
                If images are present, do not use the ‘no images’ variant

|                                             |                                                           |

|                                             | websites                                                  |
+---------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| ![An iceberg][image1]                       | **Content at scale**                                      |
|                                             |                                                           |
|                                             | Helix allows you to publish more content in shorter time  |
|                                             | with smaller teams                                        |
+---------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| ![Doors with light in the dark][image2]     | **Uncertainty eliminated**                                |
|                                             |                                                           |
|                                             | Preview content at 100% fidelity, get predictable content |
|                                             | velocity, and shorten project durations                   |
+---------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| ![A group of people around a Table][image3] | **Widen the talent pool**                                 |
|                                             |                                                           |
|                                             | Authors on Helix use Microsoft Word, Excel or Google Docs |
|                                             | and need no training                                      |
+---------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| ![HTML code in a code editor][image4]       | **The low-code way to developer productivity**            |
|                                             |                                                           |
|                                             | Say goodbye to complex APIs spanning multiple languages.  |
|                                             | Anyone with a little bit of HTML, CSS, and JS can build a |
|                                             | site on Project Helix.                                    |
+---------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| ![A rocket and a headless suit][image5]     | **Headless is here**                                      |
|                                             |                                                           |
|                                             | Go directly from Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets to the  |
|                                             | web in mere seconds. Sanitize and collect form data at    |
|                                             | extreme scale with Project Helix Forms.                   |
+---------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| ![A dial with a hand on it][image6]         | **Peak performance**                                      |
|                                             |                                                           |
|                                             | Use Project Helix's serverless architecture to meet any   |
|                                             | traffic need. Use Project Helix's PageSpeed Insights      |
|                                             | Github action to evaluate every Pull-Request for          |
|                                             | Lighthouse Score.                                         |
+---------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+

---

+----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Library Metadata**                                                                                           |
+-------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| name        | Cards (no images)                                                                                |
+-------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| description | This block is used to showcase distinct pieces of information in a                               |
|             | consistent, card-based layout, each card typically containing a title and                        |
|             | descriptive text.                                                                                |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | **Implementation**                                                                               |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | This block’s table has 1 column and multiple rows, with the first row                            |
|             | containing only the block name and optional variants in parenthesis.                             |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | Each **subsequent row** represents a single card and can include:                                |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | - **Text content (mandatory)** - in the first (and only) cell of the row. This cell can contain: |
|             |   - **Heading (optional)**                                                                       |
|             |   - **Description (optional)** - below the heading.                                              |
|             |   - **Call-to-Action (optional)** - linked text at the bottom of the cell.                       |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | When rendered, CSS and JavaScript transform each row into a card,                                |
|             | arranging them in a grid or list layout based on available space.                                |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | **When to use**                                                                                  |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | - To highlight multiple related features, products, or articles.                                 |
|             | - When you want a uniform visual style for items with distinct content.                          |
|             | - To make a set of clickable, structured elements that are easy to scan.                         |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | **When to consider another block**                                                               |
|             |                                                                                                  |
|             | - If you need just a single feature or highlight, rather than multiple                           |
|             |   cards.                                                                                         |
|             | - When your layout requires more complex components or varied styling per                        |
|             |   item.                                                                                          |
|             | - If a simpler list or table layout better fits the content.                                     |
|             | - If images are present, do not use the ‘no images’ variant                                      |
+-------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Cards**                                                                                         |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Unmatched speed**                                                                               |
|                                                                                                   |
| Helix is the fastest way to publish, create, and serve websites                                   |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Content at scale**                                                                              |
|                                                                                                   |
| Helix allows you to publish more content in shorter time with smaller teams                       |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Uncertainty eliminated**                                                                        |
|                                                                                                   |
| Preview content at 100% fidelity, get predictable content velocity, and shorten project durations |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Widen the talent pool**                                                                         |
|                                                                                                   |
| Authors on Helix use Microsoft Word, Excel or Google Docs and need no training                    |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

name: Video

textContent.value: Video

This block is used to embed a stand-alone video in a page, typically displayed with a built-in player or stylized container.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has 1 column and 2 rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                The second row includes the video source (e.g., a link to a video file or streaming URL).
                  
                    An optional poster image can be provided in this cell as well.
                  
                
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will display the video in an embedded player, allowing users to play, pause, and control the video directly on the page.
              When to use
              
                When showcasing a single video or a featured piece of audiovisual content.
                To provide a quick, embedded viewing experience without navigating away from the page.
                For tutorials, product demos, or marketing materials that rely heavily on video.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If you need multiple videos presented in a rotating or gallery format (e.g., Carousel).
                When you only need to provide a link or reference to external media without embedding.
                If you require a more comprehensive layout with additional text or media elements.

md:

| **Library Metadata**                                                    |
+-------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| name        | Video                                                     |
+-------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
| description | This block is used to embed a stand-alone video in a      |
|             | page, typically displayed with a built-in player or       |
|             | stylized container.                                       |
|             |                                                           |
|             | **Implementation**                                        |
|             |                                                           |
|             | This block’s table typically has 1 column and 2 rows,     |
|             | with the first row containing only the block name and     |
|             | optional variants.                                        |
|             |                                                           |
|             | - The **second row** includes the video source (e.g., a   |
|             |   link to a video file or streaming URL).                 |
|             |   - An optional poster image can be provided in this cell |
|             |     as well.                                              |
|             |                                                           |
|             | When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will display the video  |
|             | in an embedded player, allowing users to play, pause, and |
|             | control the video directly on the page.                   |
|             |                                                           |
|             | **When to use**                                           |
|             |                                                           |
|             | - When showcasing a single video or a featured piece of   |
|             |   audiovisual content.                                    |
|             | - To provide a quick, embedded viewing experience without |
|             |   navigating away from the page.                          |
|             | - For tutorials, product demos, or marketing materials    |
|             |   that rely heavily on video.                             |
|             |                                                           |
|             | **When to consider another block**                        |
|             |                                                           |
|             | - If you need multiple videos presented in a rotating or  |
|             |   gallery format (e.g., Carousel).                        |
|             | - When you only need to provide a link or reference to    |
|             |   external media without embedding.                       |
|             | - If you require a more comprehensive layout with         |
|             |   additional text or media elements.                      |

name: Accordion

textContent.value: Accordion

This block is used to organize content within collapsible sections, allowing users to expand or collapse each section to reveal or hide its contents.
              Implementation
              This block’s table has 2 columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                Each subsequent row represents an accordion item as 2 cells:
                  
                    Title cell (mandatory) – the clickable title or label for the accordion item.
                    Content cell (mandatory) – the body text, media, or any additional elements that will appear when this accordion item is expanded.
                  
                
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript transform each row into an accordion panel, where clicking the panel toggles the display of its content.
              When to use
              
                When you need to present multiple related topics in a compact format.
                For FAQ sections or other question-and-answer style content.
                To help users quickly scan headings and selectively view details.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content is short and doesn’t require toggling.
                When you want all details to be visible at once without user interaction.
                If there are many complex elements that need a more flexible layout.

md:
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Library Metadata**                                                                                |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| name        | Accordion                                                                             |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| description | This block is used to organize content within collapsible sections, allowing users to |
|             | expand or collapse each section to reveal or hide its contents.                       |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | **Implementation**                                                                    |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | This block’s table has 2 columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing     |
|             | only the block name and optional variants.                                            |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | - Each subsequent row represents an accordion item as 2 cells:                        |
|             |   - **Title cell (mandatory)** – the clickable title or label for the accordion item. |
|             |   - **Content cell (mandatory)** – the body text, media, or any additional elements   |
|             |     that will appear when this accordion item is expanded.                            |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | When rendered, CSS and JavaScript transform each row into an accordion panel, where   |
|             | clicking the panel toggles the display of its content.                                |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | **When to use**                                                                       |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | - When you need to present multiple related topics in a compact format.               |
|             | - For FAQ sections or other question-and-answer style content.                        |
|             | - To help users quickly scan headings and selectively view details.                   |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | **When to consider another block**                                                    |
|             |                                                                                       |
|             | - If your content is short and doesn’t require toggling.                              |
|             | - When you want all details to be visible at once without user interaction.           |
|             | - If there are many complex elements that need a more flexible layout.                |
+-------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Accordion**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, paulo scripta perfecto an duo?                                              | Aliquando sadipscing eum ea, aliquid postulant qui in. Option **vulputate** an ius, everti _efficiendi_ ex qui, inimicus liberavisse reprehendunt sit ei. |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Pri id [veniam](https://www.hlx.live/docs/) persequeris reprehendunt?                                   | Vocibus pericula temporibus id has, no quo omnium dolorem fuisset, ne quot brute gubergren per.                                                           |
|                                                                                                         |                                                                                                                                                           |
|                                                                                                         | Cu errem fastidii maiestatis sed, mel at delectus erroribus. Mea porro postea nominavi at, sumo populo vix id. Vel at apeirian evertitur.                 |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Stet ponderum ne nec?                                                                                   | Te errem impedit vel.                                                                                                                                     |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Te his mutat aeterno propriae, purto aliquip insolens ut ea?                                            | Per sale probatus cu. Et sonet facete per. Est eu viris delenit persecuti.                                                                                |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Ea officiis deserunt **referrentur** mel. Id usu tamquam lobortis _evertitur_, eum labores ancillae at. | Duo et unum liber, dicat munere putent eum ei. Ferri ludus [meliore cu pri](https://www.hlx.live/docs/).                                                  |
|                                                                                                         |                                                                                                                                                           |
| Cibo lorem urbanitas ex sea, ea amet errem vim?                                                         |                                                                                                                                                           |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

name: Hero

textContent.value: Hero

This block is used to capture users’ attention with a prominent image, a headline, and an optional call-to-action, typically placed at the top of a page.
              Implementation
              This block’s table has 1 column and 3 rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants. The single cell in the 2nd row should contain:
              
                Background Image (optional)
              
              The single cell in the 2rd row should contain:
              
                Title (optional) - styled as a Heading.
                Subheading (optional)
                Call-to-Action (optional) - text with a link.
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will display this block as a large banner, combining the background asset with text and an optional button.
              When to use
              
                When you need a strong visual statement at the top of a page.
                To highlight a key message, offer, or brand identity.
                When you want a clear, high-impact call-to-action above the fold.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If the layout requires more detailed content sections rather than a single headline.
                When page space is limited, and a large banner would distract from other priorities.
                If you need multiple content elements or a more flexible layout below the main image.

|             | 2. **Call-to-Action** (optional) - text with a link.                |

|             | optional button.                                                    |
|             |                                                                     |
|             | **When to use**                                                     |

|             | - To highlight a key message, offer, or brand identity.             |
|             | - When you want a clear, high-impact call-to-action above the fold. |
|             |                                                                     |
|             | **When to consider another block**                                  |
|             |                                                                     |
|             | - If the layout requires more detailed content sections rather than |
|             |   a single headline.                                                |
|             | - When page space is limited, and a large banner would distract     |

name: Carousel

textContent.value: Carousel

This block is used to display multiple images or slides in a rotating or swipable format, allowing users to navigate through a series of visual elements with optional text content.
              Implementation
              This block’s table has 2 columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              Each subsequent row represents a single slide and can include:
              
                Image (mandatory) - in the first cell of the row, with no other content.
                Text content (optional) - in the second cell of the row. This cell can contain:
                  
                    Title (optional) – styled as a Heading.
                    Description or Additional Content (optional)
                    Call-to-Action (optional) – linked text at the bottom of the cell.
                  
                
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript transform each row into a slide, providing navigation controls (e.g., arrows or dots) for users to move between them.
              When to use
              
                When you have multiple featured images or content pieces you want to showcase in a limited space.
                To present a dynamic gallery or promotional highlights.
                When you want to encourage user interaction by clicking or swiping through slides.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If you only have one piece of featured content, making rotation unnecessary.
                When all content should remain visible without user interaction or scrolling.
                If performance or mobile constraints make slides less user-friendly.

|             |   - **Call-to-Action (optional)** – linked text at the bottom of the cell.            |

name: Tabs

textContent.value: Tabs

This block is used to present multiple sections of content within a single container, with each section accessible by selecting its corresponding tab.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has 2 columns and multiple rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                Each subsequent row represents a single tab:
                  
                    Tab Label (mandatory) – In the first cell of the row.
                    Tab Content (mandatory) – the detailed information or media displayed when the tab is selected, in the second cell of the row.
                  
                
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript create a tabbed interface, allowing users to switch between content sections by clicking on each tab label.
              When to use
              
                When you want to organize closely related content into discrete, user-selectable sections.
                To reduce page scrolling by grouping information under labeled tabs.
                If a concise, interactive UI enhances content discoverability.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content is brief and doesn’t require multiple sections.
                When all details need to be visible at once without interaction.
                If you prefer a simpler layout, such as an accordion or single-column design.

textContent.value: Search

This block is used to let users search a site’s content by entering a keyword or phrase, returning relevant pages or documents.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has 1 column and 2 rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                The second row contains an absolute URL to the query index to search (e.g., https://main--helix-block-collection--adobe.hlx.page/block-collection/sample-search-data/query-index.json)
              
              When rendered, CSS and JavaScript will display a search input field and handle user queries, returning matching results based on your site’s query index.
              When to use
              
                When you want to give users a quick way to find specific content across your site.
                On websites with a large volume of pages or documents that users may need to locate quickly.
                If you want a straightforward, built-in search experience without custom coding.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your site has minimal or single-page content where searching isn’t necessary.
                When you prefer an external or more feature-rich custom search solution.
                If you only need filtered navigation rather than a text-based search.

name: Embed

textContent.value: Embed (video)

This block is used to embed external video content (e.g., YouTube, Vimeo) directly into your page, providing a simple way to display interactive or third-party media.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has 1 column and 2 rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                The following row should contain a single cell with a URL to the external content you want to display.
                Optionally, if the provided URL is for a video, an image can also be provided in the same table cell. This image will serve as the poster for the video.
                  
                    The image should be placed above the link in the cell.
                  
                
              
              When rendered, the CSS and JavaScript will transform each row into an embedded media component, allowing users to interact with or view the external content.
              When to use
              
                When you want to incorporate external videos directly on the page.
                To enrich your content with dynamic, third-party media.
                If providing visual or interactive content from external sources enhances the user experience.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content is purely text or image-based and doesn’t require embedding.
                When you need more design control or custom styling of third-party media.
                If you want to avoid external scripts or slow loading times associated with embeds.
Embed (social)

This block is used to embed social media content (e.g., Twitter) directly into your page, providing a simple way to display interactive or third-party media.
              Implementation
              This block’s table typically has 1 column and 2 rows, with the first row containing only the block name and optional variants.
              
                The following row should contain a single cell with a URL to the external content you want to display.
              
              When rendered, the CSS and JavaScript will transform each row into an embedded media component, allowing users to interact with or view the external content.
              When to use
              
                When you want to incorporate social media posts directly on the page.
                To enrich your content with dynamic, third-party media.
                If providing visual or interactive content from external sources enhances the user experience.
              
              When to consider another block
              
                If your content is purely text or image-based and doesn’t require embedding.
                When you need more design control or custom styling of third-party media.
                If you want to avoid external scripts or slow loading times associated with embeds.
